issue.title: Operator - form view: order of fields
issue.body:
Hello, sorry if this is not the correct place to ask this question: My team is going to release an Operator at https://github.com/redhat-openshift-ecosystem/community-operators-prod , our operator has a `openAPIV3Schema` just like this one https://github.com/redhat-openshift-ecosystem/community-operators-prod/blob/main/operators/keycloak-operator/19.0.1/manifests/keycloaks.keycloak.org.crd.yaml#L16 but I noticed that the `Form view` that shows all the Operator Fields are not rendered necessarily alphabetically neither in the same order in which the `openAPIV3Schema`'s properties were defined. Do you know if there is a way of defining the order in which the input fields of the `Form View` must be rendered? The image below is the `Form view` I'm talking about (it is just an example, not the one my team will release) 

![1-5](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2582866/189610363-72760cab-9b70-4cc0-8044-012b40593dea.png)

labels.description: Indicates that a PR is ready to be merged.

issue.body:
# Description

Error info is ambiguous when minVersion and maxVersion are wrong in the
ImageSetConfiguration, especially when using yaml.

The yaml unmarshaler parses unquoted X.Y values as a number, but users
intend that to be a semver version string.

The k8s yaml unmarshaler serializes to JSON and deserializes from JSON
in order to use the json marshaler's struct tags.

The json unmarshaler can't read a number into a string field, so a
custom UnmarshalJSON method is needed.

The custom json unmarshaling code would be simpler if MinVersion and
MaxVersion were extracted to a dedicated struct and inlined back into
ReleaseChannel, but there are a bunch of usages that would need to be
updated and I chose to prefer slightly-more-complicated unmarshaling
over clobbering history in a bunch of other places.

Bug 2029367
Fixes github issue #240

## Type of change

Please delete options that are not relevant.

- [x] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)

# How Has This Been Tested?

This is a client-side configuration parsing bug, so I wrote unit tests. Run `make test`

**Test Configuration**:
* Toolchain: go version go1.18.3 linux/amd64

# Checklist:

- [x] My code follows the style guidelines of this project
- [x] I have performed a self-review of my own code
- [x] I have commented my code, particularly in hard-to-understand areas
- [x] I have made corresponding changes to the documentation (I don't think any change is needed)
- [x] My changes generate no new warnings
- [x] I have added tests that prove my fix is effective or that my feature works
- [x] New and existing unit tests pass locally with my changes
- [x] Any dependent changes have been merged and published in downstream modules

labels.description: Referenced Bugzilla bug's severity is medium for the branch this PR is targeting.

issue.body:
When a user tries to create a new-app with a SSH based repository, `oc` fails on not being able to `git ls-remote --heads` due authentication error, i.e.:

```
$ oc new-app --v=8 --source-secret=github-repo-key --name=test-app 'git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git'
I1019 09:41:10.701737   24709 loader.go:374] Config loaded from file:  /home/otaviof/.kube/config
I1019 09:41:10.702768   24709 sourcelookup.go:316] Checking if git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git requires authentication
I1019 09:41:10.702789   24709 repository.go:450] Executing git ls-remote --heads git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git
I1019 09:41:10.702811   24709 repository.go:459] Environment:
I1019 09:41:10.702818   24709 repository.go:461] - HOME=/tmp/githome2802467764
I1019 09:41:10.702825   24709 repository.go:461] - GIT_SSH=/dev/null
I1019 09:41:10.702832   24709 repository.go:461] - GIT_CONFIG_NOSYSTEM=true
I1019 09:41:10.702837   24709 repository.go:461] - GIT_ASKPASS=true
I1019 09:41:10.704143   24709 repository.go:541] Error executing command: exit status 128
warning: Cannot check if git requires authentication.
[...]
See 'oc new-app -h' for examples.
exit status 1
``` 

This pull request removes the hardcoded `GIT_SSH=/dev/null` allowing Git to use the local SSH-Agent:

```
$ oc new-app --v=8 --source-secret=github-repo-key --name=test-app 'git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git'
I1019 09:35:20.560638   23876 loader.go:374] Config loaded from file:  /home/otaviof/.kube/config
I1019 09:35:20.561705   23876 sourcelookup.go:315] Checking if git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git requires authentication
I1019 09:35:20.561722   23876 repository.go:450] Executing git ls-remote --heads git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git
I1019 09:35:20.561742   23876 repository.go:459] Environment:
I1019 09:35:20.561747   23876 repository.go:461] - HOME=/tmp/githome2424980829
I1019 09:35:20.561750   23876 repository.go:461] - GIT_CONFIG_NOSYSTEM=true
I1019 09:35:20.561753   23876 repository.go:461] - GIT_ASKPASS=true
I1019 09:35:21.892018   23876 sourcelookup.go:94] git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git is a valid remote git repository

issue.title: [enterprise-4.11] Issue in file installing/installing_nutanix/installing-nutanix-installer-provisioned.adoc
issue.body:
### Which section(s) is the issue in?

The "Sample customized install-config.yaml file for Nutanix" section:

The example for overriding the RHCOS image refers to the VMWare OVA as opposed to the nutanix qcow2 file

```
    clusterOSImage: http://example.com/images/rhcos-47.83.202103221318-0-nutanix.x86_64.ova 
```

The "Additional Nutanix configuration parameters" section:

platform.nutanix.clusterOSImage shows as the example
```
An HTTP or HTTPS URL, optionally with a SHA-256 checksum. For example, http://example.com/images/rhcos-47.83.202103221318-0-nutanix.x86_64.ova
```

as opposed to the nutanix qcow2 file


### What needs fixing?

The 2 examples about should be updated to refer to the nutanix qcow2 file. It would be unfortunate to bring the wrong image format and block the install. I don't see any other references to the OVA or QCOW2 file in any of the nutanix specific docs from these links so this might be the only clue someone has for which RHCOS image file to download.

issue.title: [enterprise-4.10] Issue in file web_console/customizing-the-web-console.adoc

labels.name: lifecycle/rotten
labels.description: Denotes an issue or PR that has aged beyond stale and will be auto-closed.

issue.body:
<!--
Please submit only documentation-related issues with this form, or follow the
Contribute to OpenShift guidelines (https://github.com/openshift/openshift-docs/blob/main/contributing_to_docs/contributing.adoc) to submit a PR.
-->

### Which section(s) is the issue in?

`Adding YAML examples to Kubernetes resources`

### What needs fixing?

The instructions, as written, would lead a reader to modify the ConsoleYAMLSample CRD. What we want is for a user to create a new ConsoleYAMLSample.

Suggested steps:

1. From Home → Search, use the Resources dropdown to search for *ConsoleYAMLSample*.
2. Check the box next to ConsoleYAMLSample in the list.
3. Click the *Create ConsoleYAMLSample* button.
4. Edit the YAML with _$EXISTING_DOCS_YAML_SAMPLE_
5. Click Save.

A new section should also be added that explains where user can find the sample they just added:

1.  From Home → Search, use the Resources dropdown to search for *Job*.
2. Check the box next to Job in the list.
3. Click the *Create Job* button.
4. The sample is listed under the *Samples* tab on the right of the YAML editor.

issue.title: Consumption and application of Cluster Proxy and Additional Trust Bundles

labels.name: lifecycle/rotten
labels.description: Denotes an issue or PR that has aged beyond stale and will be auto-closed.

issue.body:
As it is, the cert-manager operator does not inject the needed cluster proxy and custom root CA configuration into the running Pods.

You can inject the environmental variables for `HTTP_PROXY`, `HTTPS_PROXY`, and `NO_PROXY` into the operator Subscription, which will apply them to the controller, but the controller does not pass them to the Deployments that are created by the CertManager instance.

This is useful in case a cluster is behind an outbound proxy and needs to communicate with an ACME server on the internet, such as the Sectigo OV ACME server.

labels.name: lifecycle/rotten
labels.description: Denotes an issue or PR that has aged beyond stale and will be auto-closed.

issue.body:
<!--
Please submit only documentation-related issues with this form, or follow the
Contribute to OpenShift guidelines (https://github.com/openshift/openshift-docs/blob/main/contributing_to_docs/contributing.adoc) to submit a PR.
-->

### Which section(s) is the issue in?

Verifying Argo CD self-healing behavior

### What needs fixing?

* It's not clear what purpose step 2 serves.
* Step 3 seems to be a pre-requisite for step 5, but it feels out of place and without purpose in its current location. Suggest moving into step 5. TLDR; it flows poorly and is an action without any clear purpose.
* Step 4: change *deployment.yaml* to *app/deployment.yaml* for improved clarity.
* Step 4 will not work. The prior sections instruct the reader to deploy the application using the upstream repository URL. If the reader makes and modifies a fork it will not be noticed by ArgoCD since the existing application is based on the upstream, and ArgoCD is observing that upstream for changes and not the reader's fork. The instruction to fork the repository and use it should have been specified in `Creating an application by using the Argo CD dashboard` and `Creating an application by using the oc tool`. Also, the reader would have to modify the [repoURL in app.yaml](https://github.com/evanshortiss/openshift-gitops-getting-started/blob/main/argo/app.yaml#L15) in their fork to use their fork URL.

labels.name: triage/support

issue.body:
Hi, 

We are using ansible-operator built out of the version `quay.io/operator-framework/ansible-operator:v1.22.0` and we observe their is a operator reconciliation triggered  after every 9-10 hours intervals .

Is this expected ? 

I found a defect https://github.com/operator-framework/operator-sdk/issues/3397#issuecomment-871076205 where it is mentioned  that every 10 hours default reconciliation kicks in even without any change in Custom Resource (CR) .

Is their a option or flag to control the reconciliation ?

issue.title: `--overrides` are not applied when using `oc expose service` to create a route

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Denotes an issue or PR has remained open with no activity and has become stale.

issue.body:
In previous versions of `oc` (tested with 4.9.x and 4.10.x), it was possible to create a route by exposing a service, and specify the TLS termination by providing it in an `--overrides` argument. For example:
```
oc expose service nginx --overrides='{"spec":{"tls":{"termination":"reencrypt"}}}'
```

But in a recent 4.11.x version of `oc`, this does not work as intended - the route is created, but does not have the `reencrypt` setting.

Other things that could be specified in the overrides (ie annotations) are also being ignored in the latest version. I think the issue is caused by no longer using a generator for the route, and instead creating it directly, here: https://github.com/openshift/oc/blob/master/pkg/cli/expose/expose.go#L187

## Steps to recreate the problem

1. Create an nginx deployment: `oc apply -f https://k8s.io/examples/application/deployment.yaml`
2. Expose the deployment as a service: `oc expose deployment nginx-deployment`
3. Expose the service as a route with an override: `oc expose service nginx-deployment --overrides='{"spec":{"tls":{"termination":"reencrypt"}}}'`
4. Check the created route:

```
# With oc 4.9.x : 
❯ oc get route nginx-deployment -o yaml | grep -A 10 spec:
spec:
  host: [elided]
  port:
    targetPort: 80
  tls:
    termination: reencrypt
  to:
    kind: Service
    name: nginx-deployment
    weight: 100
  wildcardPolicy: None

# With oc 4.11.x : 
❯ oc get route nginx-deployment -o yaml | grep -A 10 spec:
spec:
  host: [elided]
  port:
    targetPort: 80
  to:
    kind: Service
    name: nginx-deployment
    weight: 100
  wildcardPolicy: None
status:
  ingress:
```

issue.title: Have support for building multi-arch operator images in Makefile and Dockerfile

labels.name: lifecycle/rotten
labels.description: Denotes an issue or PR that has aged beyond stale and will be auto-closed.

labels.name: language/go
labels.description: Issue is related to a Go operator project

issue.body:
## Feature Request

#### Describe the problem you need a feature to resolve.

Make easier the build of multi-arch operators.
Today the Dockerfile generated by operator-sdk init is explicitly setting GOARCH to amd64
RUN CGO_ENABLED=0 GOOS=linux GOARCH=amd64 GO111MODULE=on go build -a -o manager main.go
The Makefile generated by the same command is explicitly using "docker build":
docker build -t ${IMG} .

Support for multi-arch builds have been requested a few times in the past, like here:
https://github.com/operator-framework/operator-sdk/issues/3071

#### Describe the solution you'd like.

A possible approach would be to add a --multi-arch flag to operator-sdk init with default value to false for backward compatibility. When set to true
- the generated Dockerfile would have:
RUN CGO_ENABLED=0 GOOS=linux GOARCH=$TARGETPLATFORM GO111MODULE=on go build -a -o manager main.go
- the Makefile would use buildx:
docker buildx build --platform ${TARGET_PLATFORMS} -t ${IMG}.
TARGET_PLATFORMS could default to amd64 in the Makefile

A similar approach could be used for more customization like using buildah/podman instead of docker

Benefits:
- Better user experience: multi-arch builds supported directly by setting a flag. No need to retrieve the required commands and change generated files
- Control by the SDK project of the Makefile and Dockerfile customization so that upgrades to newer versions of the SDK may not override changes made by users for supporting multi-arch builds

/language go

issue.title: Bug 2029367: fix(config): Parse X.Y format minVersion and maxVersion

labels.name: bugzilla/severity-medium
labels.description: Referenced Bugzilla bug's severity is medium for the branch this PR is targeting.

labels.name: ok-to-test
labels.description: Indicates a non-member PR verified by an org member that is safe to test.

labels.name: approved
labels.description: Indicates a PR has been approved by an approver from all required OWNERS files.

labels.name: bugzilla/invalid-bug
labels.description: Indicates that a referenced Bugzilla bug is invalid for the branch this PR is targeting.

labels.name: lgtm
labels.description: Indicates that a PR is ready to be merged.

issue.body:
# Description

Error info is ambiguous when minVersion and maxVersion are wrong in the
ImageSetConfiguration, especially when using yaml.

The yaml unmarshaler parses unquoted X.Y values as a number, but users
intend that to be a semver version string.

The k8s yaml unmarshaler serializes to JSON and deserializes from JSON
in order to use the json marshaler's struct tags.

The json unmarshaler can't read a number into a string field, so a
custom UnmarshalJSON method is needed.

The custom json unmarshaling code would be simpler if MinVersion and
MaxVersion were extracted to a dedicated struct and inlined back into
ReleaseChannel, but there are a bunch of usages that would need to be
updated and I chose to prefer slightly-more-complicated unmarshaling
over clobbering history in a bunch of other places.

Bug 2029367
Fixes github issue #240

## Type of change

Please delete options that are not relevant.

- [x] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)

# How Has This Been Tested?

This is a client-side configuration parsing bug, so I wrote unit tests. Run `make test`

**Test Configuration**:
* Toolchain: go version go1.18.3 linux/amd64

- [x] My code follows the style guidelines of this project
- [x] I have performed a self-review of my own code
- [x] I have commented my code, particularly in hard-to-understand areas

issue.body:
When a user tries to create a new-app with a SSH based repository, `oc` fails on not being able to `git ls-remote --heads` due authentication error, i.e.:

```
$ oc new-app --v=8 --source-secret=github-repo-key --name=test-app 'git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git'
I1019 09:41:10.701737   24709 loader.go:374] Config loaded from file:  /home/otaviof/.kube/config
I1019 09:41:10.702768   24709 sourcelookup.go:316] Checking if git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git requires authentication
I1019 09:41:10.702789   24709 repository.go:450] Executing git ls-remote --heads git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git
I1019 09:41:10.702811   24709 repository.go:459] Environment:
I1019 09:41:10.702818   24709 repository.go:461] - HOME=/tmp/githome2802467764
I1019 09:41:10.702825   24709 repository.go:461] - GIT_SSH=/dev/null
I1019 09:41:10.702832   24709 repository.go:461] - GIT_CONFIG_NOSYSTEM=true
I1019 09:41:10.702837   24709 repository.go:461] - GIT_ASKPASS=true
I1019 09:41:10.704143   24709 repository.go:541] Error executing command: exit status 128
warning: Cannot check if git requires authentication.
[...]
See 'oc new-app -h' for examples.
exit status 1
``` 

This pull request removes the hardcoded `GIT_SSH=/dev/null` allowing Git to use the local SSH-Agent:

```
$ oc new-app --v=8 --source-secret=github-repo-key --name=test-app 'git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git'
I1019 09:35:20.560638   23876 loader.go:374] Config loaded from file:  /home/otaviof/.kube/config
I1019 09:35:20.561705   23876 sourcelookup.go:315] Checking if git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git requires authentication
I1019 09:35:20.561722   23876 repository.go:450] Executing git ls-remote --heads git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git
I1019 09:35:20.561742   23876 repository.go:459] Environment:

I1019 09:35:20.561750   23876 repository.go:461] - GIT_CONFIG_NOSYSTEM=true
I1019 09:35:20.561753   23876 repository.go:461] - GIT_ASKPASS=true
I1019 09:35:21.892018   23876 sourcelookup.go:94] git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git is a valid remote git repository
I1019 09:35:21.892044   23876 newapp.go:318] treating git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git as possible source repo
[...]
--> Success

     'oc expose service/test-app'

```

issue.title: Special debug code to execute after scenario step in case of special test case failures.

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Denotes an issue or PR has remained open with no activity and has become stale.

issue.body:
As you see in both [OCPQE-8172](https://issues.redhat.com/browse/OCPQE-8172) and [OCPQE-8117](https://issues.redhat.com/browse/OCPQE-8117) tickets, in these cases, it is difficult for us to debug test case failures or taking longer time to identify the root cause. To minimize the effort on debugging such failures , we want to introduce certain debug code to execute right after the unexpected failures during execution.
I have investigated with cucushift framework ( with my limited knowledge :) ) and made few dummy changes and that makes execution of debug statements "after scenario" step. The intention is NOT to execute debug statements for every case but need to execute only in case of failures w.r.t kube-apiserver such as,
1. xxxx:6443 connection is refused.
2. xxxx:6443 timeout.
3. server is currently unable to handle the request (get projects.project.openshift.io)
Currently i'm unable to get the test case result or it's scope to make such decision for above code. I would need your review and suggestions to achieve the solution.
Note: These are random failures and not stick to any specific test case , Hence I see that it's needs to be handled in core instead of step implementation.
Attached local execution results for both positive and negative scenarios - http://pastebin.test.redhat.com/1043194
@wangke19 @liangxia @qe-productivity-team Please share your thoughts.

issue.body:
Currently tests both `non-ccs` and `ccs` cluster creation using OCM.

This script assumes you're already logged into whatever OCM environment you are attempting to test.

This script also assumes you have a valid set of credentials for an IAM User: `osdCCSAdmin` in your `~/.aws/credentials` file (you pass the profile name in as the parameter).

Example:

```
$ cat ~/.aws/credentials
[osd-staging-2-ccsadmin]
aws_access_key_id = myaccesskeyid
aws_secret_access_key_id = mysecretaccesskeyid
```

Given the above file, you would call the script as such: `./hack/scripts/validate_deployment.sh -p osd-staging-2-ccsadmin`

This script runs the creation in parallel, allowing you to run the script and just wait for the output to finish.  The script also only waits for the cluster to move from `pending` to `installing` as once the cluster is `installing` the work of AWS Account Operator is complete.

Future work: Script out STS creation.

labels.description: Indicates that a PR is ready to be merged.

issue.body:
# Description

Error info is ambiguous when minVersion and maxVersion are wrong in the
ImageSetConfiguration, especially when using yaml.

The yaml unmarshaler parses unquoted X.Y values as a number, but users
intend that to be a semver version string.

The k8s yaml unmarshaler serializes to JSON and deserializes from JSON
in order to use the json marshaler's struct tags.

The json unmarshaler can't read a number into a string field, so a
custom UnmarshalJSON method is needed.

The custom json unmarshaling code would be simpler if MinVersion and
MaxVersion were extracted to a dedicated struct and inlined back into
ReleaseChannel, but there are a bunch of usages that would need to be
updated and I chose to prefer slightly-more-complicated unmarshaling
over clobbering history in a bunch of other places.

Bug 2029367
Fixes github issue #240

## Type of change

Please delete options that are not relevant.

- [x] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)

# How Has This Been Tested?

This is a client-side configuration parsing bug, so I wrote unit tests. Run `make test`

**Test Configuration**:
* Toolchain: go version go1.18.3 linux/amd64

# Checklist:

- [x] My code follows the style guidelines of this project
- [x] I have performed a self-review of my own code
- [x] I have commented my code, particularly in hard-to-understand areas
- [x] I have made corresponding changes to the documentation (I don't think any change is needed)
- [x] My changes generate no new warnings
- [x] I have added tests that prove my fix is effective or that my feature works
- [x] New and existing unit tests pass locally with my changes
- [x] Any dependent changes have been merged and published in downstream modules

issue.body:
When a user tries to create a new-app with a SSH based repository, `oc` fails on not being able to `git ls-remote --heads` due authentication error, i.e.:

```
$ oc new-app --v=8 --source-secret=github-repo-key --name=test-app 'git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git'
I1019 09:41:10.701737   24709 loader.go:374] Config loaded from file:  /home/otaviof/.kube/config
I1019 09:41:10.702768   24709 sourcelookup.go:316] Checking if git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git requires authentication
I1019 09:41:10.702789   24709 repository.go:450] Executing git ls-remote --heads git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git
I1019 09:41:10.702811   24709 repository.go:459] Environment:
I1019 09:41:10.702818   24709 repository.go:461] - HOME=/tmp/githome2802467764
I1019 09:41:10.702825   24709 repository.go:461] - GIT_SSH=/dev/null
I1019 09:41:10.702832   24709 repository.go:461] - GIT_CONFIG_NOSYSTEM=true
I1019 09:41:10.702837   24709 repository.go:461] - GIT_ASKPASS=true
I1019 09:41:10.704143   24709 repository.go:541] Error executing command: exit status 128
warning: Cannot check if git requires authentication.
[...]
See 'oc new-app -h' for examples.
exit status 1
``` 

This pull request removes the hardcoded `GIT_SSH=/dev/null` allowing Git to use the local SSH-Agent:

```
$ oc new-app --v=8 --source-secret=github-repo-key --name=test-app 'git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git'
I1019 09:35:20.560638   23876 loader.go:374] Config loaded from file:  /home/otaviof/.kube/config
I1019 09:35:20.561705   23876 sourcelookup.go:315] Checking if git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git requires authentication
I1019 09:35:20.561722   23876 repository.go:450] Executing git ls-remote --heads git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git
I1019 09:35:20.561742   23876 repository.go:459] Environment:
I1019 09:35:20.561747   23876 repository.go:461] - HOME=/tmp/githome2424980829
I1019 09:35:20.561750   23876 repository.go:461] - GIT_CONFIG_NOSYSTEM=true
I1019 09:35:20.561753   23876 repository.go:461] - GIT_ASKPASS=true
I1019 09:35:21.892018   23876 sourcelookup.go:94] git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git is a valid remote git repository
I1019 09:35:21.892044   23876 newapp.go:318] treating git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git as possible source repo
[...]
--> Success
    Build scheduled, use 'oc logs -f buildconfig/test-app' to track its progress.
    Application is not exposed. You can expose services to the outside world by executing one or more of the commands below:
     'oc expose service/test-app'
    Run 'oc status' to view your app.
```

issue.title: [enterprise-4.11] Issue in file installing/installing_nutanix/installing-nutanix-installer-provisioned.adoc
issue.body:
### Which section(s) is the issue in?

The "Sample customized install-config.yaml file for Nutanix" section:

The example for overriding the RHCOS image refers to the VMWare OVA as opposed to the nutanix qcow2 file

```
    clusterOSImage: http://example.com/images/rhcos-47.83.202103221318-0-nutanix.x86_64.ova 
```

The "Additional Nutanix configuration parameters" section:

platform.nutanix.clusterOSImage shows as the example
```
An HTTP or HTTPS URL, optionally with a SHA-256 checksum. For example, http://example.com/images/rhcos-47.83.202103221318-0-nutanix.x86_64.ova
```

as opposed to the nutanix qcow2 file


### What needs fixing?

The 2 examples about should be updated to refer to the nutanix qcow2 file. It would be unfortunate to bring the wrong image format and block the install. I don't see any other references to the OVA or QCOW2 file in any of the nutanix specific docs from these links so this might be the only clue someone has for which RHCOS image file to download.

<!--
Please submit only documentation-related issues with this form, or follow the
Contribute to OpenShift guidelines (https://github.com/openshift/openshift-docs/blob/main/contributing_to_docs/contributing.adoc) to submit a PR.
-->

### Which section(s) is the issue in?

`Adding YAML examples to Kubernetes resources`

### What needs fixing?

The instructions, as written, would lead a reader to modify the ConsoleYAMLSample CRD. What we want is for a user to create a new ConsoleYAMLSample.

Suggested steps:

1. From Home → Search, use the Resources dropdown to search for *ConsoleYAMLSample*.
2. Check the box next to ConsoleYAMLSample in the list.
3. Click the *Create ConsoleYAMLSample* button.
4. Edit the YAML with _$EXISTING_DOCS_YAML_SAMPLE_
5. Click Save.

A new section should also be added that explains where user can find the sample they just added:

1.  From Home → Search, use the Resources dropdown to search for *Job*.
2. Check the box next to Job in the list.
3. Click the *Create Job* button.
4. The sample is listed under the *Samples* tab on the right of the YAML editor.

issue.title: Consumption and application of Cluster Proxy and Additional Trust Bundles

labels.name: lifecycle/rotten
labels.description: Denotes an issue or PR that has aged beyond stale and will be auto-closed.

issue.body:
As it is, the cert-manager operator does not inject the needed cluster proxy and custom root CA configuration into the running Pods.

You can inject the environmental variables for `HTTP_PROXY`, `HTTPS_PROXY`, and `NO_PROXY` into the operator Subscription, which will apply them to the controller, but the controller does not pass them to the Deployments that are created by the CertManager instance.

This is useful in case a cluster is behind an outbound proxy and needs to communicate with an ACME server on the internet, such as the Sectigo OV ACME server.

labels.name: lifecycle/rotten
labels.description: Denotes an issue or PR that has aged beyond stale and will be auto-closed.

issue.body:
<!--
Please submit only documentation-related issues with this form, or follow the
Contribute to OpenShift guidelines (https://github.com/openshift/openshift-docs/blob/main/contributing_to_docs/contributing.adoc) to submit a PR.
-->

### Which section(s) is the issue in?

Verifying Argo CD self-healing behavior

### What needs fixing?

* It's not clear what purpose step 2 serves.
* Step 3 seems to be a pre-requisite for step 5, but it feels out of place and without purpose in its current location. Suggest moving into step 5. TLDR; it flows poorly and is an action without any clear purpose.
* Step 4: change *deployment.yaml* to *app/deployment.yaml* for improved clarity.
* Step 4 will not work. The prior sections instruct the reader to deploy the application using the upstream repository URL. If the reader makes and modifies a fork it will not be noticed by ArgoCD since the existing application is based on the upstream, and ArgoCD is observing that upstream for changes and not the reader's fork. The instruction to fork the repository and use it should have been specified in `Creating an application by using the Argo CD dashboard` and `Creating an application by using the oc tool`. Also, the reader would have to modify the [repoURL in app.yaml](https://github.com/evanshortiss/openshift-gitops-getting-started/blob/main/argo/app.yaml#L15) in their fork to use their fork URL.

issue.title: ansible-operator reconciliation time interval

labels.name: triage/support
labels.description: Indicates an issue that is a support question.

issue.body:
Hi, 

We are using ansible-operator built out of the version `quay.io/operator-framework/ansible-operator:v1.22.0` and we observe their is a operator reconciliation triggered  after every 9-10 hours intervals .

Is this expected ? 

I found a defect https://github.com/operator-framework/operator-sdk/issues/3397#issuecomment-871076205 where it is mentioned  that every 10 hours default reconciliation kicks in even without any change in Custom Resource (CR) .

Is their a option or flag to control the reconciliation ?

issue.title: `--overrides` are not applied when using `oc expose service` to create a route

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Denotes an issue or PR has remained open with no activity and has become stale.

issue.body:
In previous versions of `oc` (tested with 4.9.x and 4.10.x), it was possible to create a route by exposing a service, and specify the TLS termination by providing it in an `--overrides` argument. For example:
```
oc expose service nginx --overrides='{"spec":{"tls":{"termination":"reencrypt"}}}'
```

But in a recent 4.11.x version of `oc`, this does not work as intended - the route is created, but does not have the `reencrypt` setting.

Other things that could be specified in the overrides (ie annotations) are also being ignored in the latest version. I think the issue is caused by no longer using a generator for the route, and instead creating it directly, here: https://github.com/openshift/oc/blob/master/pkg/cli/expose/expose.go#L187

## Steps to recreate the problem

1. Create an nginx deployment: `oc apply -f https://k8s.io/examples/application/deployment.yaml`
2. Expose the deployment as a service: `oc expose deployment nginx-deployment`
3. Expose the service as a route with an override: `oc expose service nginx-deployment --overrides='{"spec":{"tls":{"termination":"reencrypt"}}}'`
4. Check the created route:

```
# With oc 4.9.x : 
❯ oc get route nginx-deployment -o yaml | grep -A 10 spec:
spec:
  host: [elided]
  port:
    targetPort: 80
  tls:
    termination: reencrypt
  to:
    kind: Service
    name: nginx-deployment
    weight: 100
  wildcardPolicy: None

# With oc 4.11.x : 
❯ oc get route nginx-deployment -o yaml | grep -A 10 spec:
spec:
  host: [elided]
  port:
    targetPort: 80
  to:
    kind: Service
    name: nginx-deployment
    weight: 100
  wildcardPolicy: None
status:
  ingress:
```

issue.title: Have support for building multi-arch operator images in Makefile and Dockerfile

labels.name: lifecycle/rotten
labels.description: Denotes an issue or PR that has aged beyond stale and will be auto-closed.

labels.name: language/go
labels.description: Issue is related to a Go operator project

issue.body:
## Feature Request

#### Describe the problem you need a feature to resolve.

Make easier the build of multi-arch operators.
Today the Dockerfile generated by operator-sdk init is explicitly setting GOARCH to amd64
RUN CGO_ENABLED=0 GOOS=linux GOARCH=amd64 GO111MODULE=on go build -a -o manager main.go
The Makefile generated by the same command is explicitly using "docker build":
docker build -t ${IMG} .

Support for multi-arch builds have been requested a few times in the past, like here:
https://github.com/operator-framework/operator-sdk/issues/3071

#### Describe the solution you'd like.

A possible approach would be to add a --multi-arch flag to operator-sdk init with default value to false for backward compatibility. When set to true
- the generated Dockerfile would have:
RUN CGO_ENABLED=0 GOOS=linux GOARCH=$TARGETPLATFORM GO111MODULE=on go build -a -o manager main.go
- the Makefile would use buildx:
docker buildx build --platform ${TARGET_PLATFORMS} -t ${IMG}.
TARGET_PLATFORMS could default to amd64 in the Makefile

A similar approach could be used for more customization like using buildah/podman instead of docker

Benefits:
- Better user experience: multi-arch builds supported directly by setting a flag. No need to retrieve the required commands and change generated files
- Control by the SDK project of the Makefile and Dockerfile customization so that upgrades to newer versions of the SDK may not override changes made by users for supporting multi-arch builds

/language go

issue.title: Bug 2029367: fix(config): Parse X.Y format minVersion and maxVersion

labels.name: bugzilla/severity-medium
labels.description: Referenced Bugzilla bug's severity is medium for the branch this PR is targeting.

labels.name: ok-to-test
labels.description: Indicates a non-member PR verified by an org member that is safe to test.

labels.name: approved
labels.description: Indicates a PR has been approved by an approver from all required OWNERS files.

labels.name: bugzilla/invalid-bug
labels.description: Indicates that a referenced Bugzilla bug is invalid for the branch this PR is targeting.

labels.name: lgtm
labels.description: Indicates that a PR is ready to be merged.

issue.body:
# Description

Error info is ambiguous when minVersion and maxVersion are wrong in the
ImageSetConfiguration, especially when using yaml.

The yaml unmarshaler parses unquoted X.Y values as a number, but users
intend that to be a semver version string.

The k8s yaml unmarshaler serializes to JSON and deserializes from JSON
in order to use the json marshaler's struct tags.

The json unmarshaler can't read a number into a string field, so a
custom UnmarshalJSON method is needed.

The custom json unmarshaling code would be simpler if MinVersion and
MaxVersion were extracted to a dedicated struct and inlined back into
ReleaseChannel, but there are a bunch of usages that would need to be
updated and I chose to prefer slightly-more-complicated unmarshaling
over clobbering history in a bunch of other places.

Bug 2029367
Fixes github issue #240

## Type of change

Please delete options that are not relevant.

- [x] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)

# How Has This Been Tested?

This is a client-side configuration parsing bug, so I wrote unit tests. Run `make test`

**Test Configuration**:
* Toolchain: go version go1.18.3 linux/amd64

# Checklist:

- [x] My code follows the style guidelines of this project
- [x] I have performed a self-review of my own code
- [x] I have commented my code, particularly in hard-to-understand areas
- [x] I have made corresponding changes to the documentation (I don't think any change is needed)
- [x] My changes generate no new warnings
- [x] I have added tests that prove my fix is effective or that my feature works
- [x] New and existing unit tests pass locally with my changes
- [x] Any dependent changes have been merged and published in downstream modules

issue.body:
When a user tries to create a new-app with a SSH based repository, `oc` fails on not being able to `git ls-remote --heads` due authentication error, i.e.:

```
$ oc new-app --v=8 --source-secret=github-repo-key --name=test-app 'git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git'
I1019 09:41:10.701737   24709 loader.go:374] Config loaded from file:  /home/otaviof/.kube/config
I1019 09:41:10.702768   24709 sourcelookup.go:316] Checking if git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git requires authentication
I1019 09:41:10.702789   24709 repository.go:450] Executing git ls-remote --heads git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git
I1019 09:41:10.702811   24709 repository.go:459] Environment:
I1019 09:41:10.702818   24709 repository.go:461] - HOME=/tmp/githome2802467764
I1019 09:41:10.702825   24709 repository.go:461] - GIT_SSH=/dev/null
I1019 09:41:10.702832   24709 repository.go:461] - GIT_CONFIG_NOSYSTEM=true
I1019 09:41:10.702837   24709 repository.go:461] - GIT_ASKPASS=true
I1019 09:41:10.704143   24709 repository.go:541] Error executing command: exit status 128
warning: Cannot check if git requires authentication.
[...]
See 'oc new-app -h' for examples.
exit status 1
``` 

This pull request removes the hardcoded `GIT_SSH=/dev/null` allowing Git to use the local SSH-Agent:

```
$ oc new-app --v=8 --source-secret=github-repo-key --name=test-app 'git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git'
I1019 09:35:20.560638   23876 loader.go:374] Config loaded from file:  /home/otaviof/.kube/config
I1019 09:35:20.561705   23876 sourcelookup.go:315] Checking if git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git requires authentication
I1019 09:35:20.561722   23876 repository.go:450] Executing git ls-remote --heads git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git
I1019 09:35:20.561742   23876 repository.go:459] Environment:
I1019 09:35:20.561747   23876 repository.go:461] - HOME=/tmp/githome2424980829
I1019 09:35:20.561750   23876 repository.go:461] - GIT_CONFIG_NOSYSTEM=true
I1019 09:35:20.561753   23876 repository.go:461] - GIT_ASKPASS=true
I1019 09:35:21.892018   23876 sourcelookup.go:94] git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git is a valid remote git repository
I1019 09:35:21.892044   23876 newapp.go:318] treating git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git as possible source repo
[...]
--> Success
    Build scheduled, use 'oc logs -f buildconfig/test-app' to track its progress.
    Application is not exposed. You can expose services to the outside world by executing one or more of the commands below:
     'oc expose service/test-app'

issue.title: Special debug code to execute after scenario step in case of special test case failures.

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Denotes an issue or PR has remained open with no activity and has become stale.

issue.body:
As you see in both [OCPQE-8172](https://issues.redhat.com/browse/OCPQE-8172) and [OCPQE-8117](https://issues.redhat.com/browse/OCPQE-8117) tickets, in these cases, it is difficult for us to debug test case failures or taking longer time to identify the root cause. To minimize the effort on debugging such failures , we want to introduce certain debug code to execute right after the unexpected failures during execution.
I have investigated with cucushift framework ( with my limited knowledge :) ) and made few dummy changes and that makes execution of debug statements "after scenario" step. The intention is NOT to execute debug statements for every case but need to execute only in case of failures w.r.t kube-apiserver such as,
1. xxxx:6443 connection is refused.
2. xxxx:6443 timeout.
3. server is currently unable to handle the request (get projects.project.openshift.io)
Currently i'm unable to get the test case result or it's scope to make such decision for above code. I would need your review and suggestions to achieve the solution.
Note: These are random failures and not stick to any specific test case , Hence I see that it's needs to be handled in core instead of step implementation.
Attached local execution results for both positive and negative scenarios - http://pastebin.test.redhat.com/1043194
@wangke19 @liangxia @qe-productivity-team Please share your thoughts.

labels.name: lifecycle/rotten
labels.description: Denotes an issue or PR that has aged beyond stale and will be auto-closed.

labels.name: approved
labels.description: Indicates a PR has been approved by an approver from all required OWNERS files.

issue.body:
Currently tests both `non-ccs` and `ccs` cluster creation using OCM.

This script assumes you're already logged into whatever OCM environment you are attempting to test.

This script also assumes you have a valid set of credentials for an IAM User: `osdCCSAdmin` in your `~/.aws/credentials` file (you pass the profile name in as the parameter).

Example:

```
$ cat ~/.aws/credentials
[osd-staging-2-ccsadmin]
aws_access_key_id = myaccesskeyid
aws_secret_access_key_id = mysecretaccesskeyid
```

Given the above file, you would call the script as such: `./hack/scripts/validate_deployment.sh -p osd-staging-2-ccsadmin`

This script runs the creation in parallel, allowing you to run the script and just wait for the output to finish.  The script also only waits for the cluster to move from `pending` to `installing` as once the cluster is `installing` the work of AWS Account Operator is complete.

Future work: Script out STS creation.

issue.body:
# Description

Error info is ambiguous when minVersion and maxVersion are wrong in the
ImageSetConfiguration, especially when using yaml.

The yaml unmarshaler parses unquoted X.Y values as a number, but users
intend that to be a semver version string.

The k8s yaml unmarshaler serializes to JSON and deserializes from JSON
in order to use the json marshaler's struct tags.

The json unmarshaler can't read a number into a string field, so a
custom UnmarshalJSON method is needed.

The custom json unmarshaling code would be simpler if MinVersion and
MaxVersion were extracted to a dedicated struct and inlined back into
ReleaseChannel, but there are a bunch of usages that would need to be
updated and I chose to prefer slightly-more-complicated unmarshaling
over clobbering history in a bunch of other places.

Bug 2029367
Fixes github issue #240

## Type of change

Please delete options that are not relevant.

- [x] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)

# How Has This Been Tested?

This is a client-side configuration parsing bug, so I wrote unit tests. Run `make test`

**Test Configuration**:
* Toolchain: go version go1.18.3 linux/amd64

- [x] My code follows the style guidelines of this project
- [x] I have performed a self-review of my own code
- [x] I have commented my code, particularly in hard-to-understand areas

labels.description: Referenced Bugzilla bug's severity is medium for the branch this PR is targeting.

issue.body:
When a user tries to create a new-app with a SSH based repository, `oc` fails on not being able to `git ls-remote --heads` due authentication error, i.e.:

```
$ oc new-app --v=8 --source-secret=github-repo-key --name=test-app 'git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git'
I1019 09:41:10.701737   24709 loader.go:374] Config loaded from file:  /home/otaviof/.kube/config
I1019 09:41:10.702768   24709 sourcelookup.go:316] Checking if git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git requires authentication
I1019 09:41:10.702789   24709 repository.go:450] Executing git ls-remote --heads git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git
I1019 09:41:10.702811   24709 repository.go:459] Environment:
I1019 09:41:10.702818   24709 repository.go:461] - HOME=/tmp/githome2802467764
I1019 09:41:10.702825   24709 repository.go:461] - GIT_SSH=/dev/null
I1019 09:41:10.702832   24709 repository.go:461] - GIT_CONFIG_NOSYSTEM=true
I1019 09:41:10.702837   24709 repository.go:461] - GIT_ASKPASS=true
I1019 09:41:10.704143   24709 repository.go:541] Error executing command: exit status 128
warning: Cannot check if git requires authentication.
[...]
See 'oc new-app -h' for examples.
exit status 1
``` 

This pull request removes the hardcoded `GIT_SSH=/dev/null` allowing Git to use the local SSH-Agent:

```
$ oc new-app --v=8 --source-secret=github-repo-key --name=test-app 'git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git'

issue.title: [enterprise-4.11] Issue in file installing/installing_nutanix/installing-nutanix-installer-provisioned.adoc
issue.body:
### Which section(s) is the issue in?

The "Sample customized install-config.yaml file for Nutanix" section:

The example for overriding the RHCOS image refers to the VMWare OVA as opposed to the nutanix qcow2 file

```
    clusterOSImage: http://example.com/images/rhcos-47.83.202103221318-0-nutanix.x86_64.ova 
```

The "Additional Nutanix configuration parameters" section:

platform.nutanix.clusterOSImage shows as the example
```
An HTTP or HTTPS URL, optionally with a SHA-256 checksum. For example, http://example.com/images/rhcos-47.83.202103221318-0-nutanix.x86_64.ova
```

as opposed to the nutanix qcow2 file


### What needs fixing?

The 2 examples about should be updated to refer to the nutanix qcow2 file. It would be unfortunate to bring the wrong image format and block the install. I don't see any other references to the OVA or QCOW2 file in any of the nutanix specific docs from these links so this might be the only clue someone has for which RHCOS image file to download.

labels.name: lifecycle/rotten
labels.description: Denotes an issue or PR that has aged beyond stale and will be auto-closed.

issue.body:
<!--
Please submit only documentation-related issues with this form, or follow the
Contribute to OpenShift guidelines (https://github.com/openshift/openshift-docs/blob/main/contributing_to_docs/contributing.adoc) to submit a PR.
-->

### Which section(s) is the issue in?

`Adding YAML examples to Kubernetes resources`

### What needs fixing?

The instructions, as written, would lead a reader to modify the ConsoleYAMLSample CRD. What we want is for a user to create a new ConsoleYAMLSample.

Suggested steps:

1. From Home → Search, use the Resources dropdown to search for *ConsoleYAMLSample*.
2. Check the box next to ConsoleYAMLSample in the list.
3. Click the *Create ConsoleYAMLSample* button.
4. Edit the YAML with _$EXISTING_DOCS_YAML_SAMPLE_
5. Click Save.

A new section should also be added that explains where user can find the sample they just added:

1.  From Home → Search, use the Resources dropdown to search for *Job*.
2. Check the box next to Job in the list.
3. Click the *Create Job* button.
4. The sample is listed under the *Samples* tab on the right of the YAML editor.

issue.title: Consumption and application of Cluster Proxy and Additional Trust Bundles

labels.name: lifecycle/rotten
labels.description: Denotes an issue or PR that has aged beyond stale and will be auto-closed.

issue.body:
As it is, the cert-manager operator does not inject the needed cluster proxy and custom root CA configuration into the running Pods.

You can inject the environmental variables for `HTTP_PROXY`, `HTTPS_PROXY`, and `NO_PROXY` into the operator Subscription, which will apply them to the controller, but the controller does not pass them to the Deployments that are created by the CertManager instance.

This is useful in case a cluster is behind an outbound proxy and needs to communicate with an ACME server on the internet, such as the Sectigo OV ACME server.

issue.title: [enterprise-4.10] Issue in file cicd/gitops/deploying-a-spring-boot-application-with-argo-cd.adoc

labels.name: lifecycle/rotten
labels.description: Denotes an issue or PR that has aged beyond stale and will be auto-closed.

issue.body:
<!--
Please submit only documentation-related issues with this form, or follow the
Contribute to OpenShift guidelines (https://github.com/openshift/openshift-docs/blob/main/contributing_to_docs/contributing.adoc) to submit a PR.
-->

### Which section(s) is the issue in?

Verifying Argo CD self-healing behavior

### What needs fixing?

* It's not clear what purpose step 2 serves.
* Step 3 seems to be a pre-requisite for step 5, but it feels out of place and without purpose in its current location. Suggest moving into step 5. TLDR; it flows poorly and is an action without any clear purpose.
* Step 4: change *deployment.yaml* to *app/deployment.yaml* for improved clarity.
* Step 4 will not work. The prior sections instruct the reader to deploy the application using the upstream repository URL. If the reader makes and modifies a fork it will not be noticed by ArgoCD since the existing application is based on the upstream, and ArgoCD is observing that upstream for changes and not the reader's fork. The instruction to fork the repository and use it should have been specified in `Creating an application by using the Argo CD dashboard` and `Creating an application by using the oc tool`. Also, the reader would have to modify the [repoURL in app.yaml](https://github.com/evanshortiss/openshift-gitops-getting-started/blob/main/argo/app.yaml#L15) in their fork to use their fork URL.

issue.title: ansible-operator reconciliation time interval

labels.name: triage/support
labels.description: Indicates an issue that is a support question.

issue.body:
Hi, 

We are using ansible-operator built out of the version `quay.io/operator-framework/ansible-operator:v1.22.0` and we observe their is a operator reconciliation triggered  after every 9-10 hours intervals .

Is this expected ? 

I found a defect https://github.com/operator-framework/operator-sdk/issues/3397#issuecomment-871076205 where it is mentioned  that every 10 hours default reconciliation kicks in even without any change in Custom Resource (CR) .

Is their a option or flag to control the reconciliation ?

issue.title: `--overrides` are not applied when using `oc expose service` to create a route

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Denotes an issue or PR has remained open with no activity and has become stale.

issue.body:
In previous versions of `oc` (tested with 4.9.x and 4.10.x), it was possible to create a route by exposing a service, and specify the TLS termination by providing it in an `--overrides` argument. For example:
```
oc expose service nginx --overrides='{"spec":{"tls":{"termination":"reencrypt"}}}'
```

But in a recent 4.11.x version of `oc`, this does not work as intended - the route is created, but does not have the `reencrypt` setting.

Other things that could be specified in the overrides (ie annotations) are also being ignored in the latest version. I think the issue is caused by no longer using a generator for the route, and instead creating it directly, here: https://github.com/openshift/oc/blob/master/pkg/cli/expose/expose.go#L187

## Steps to recreate the problem

1. Create an nginx deployment: `oc apply -f https://k8s.io/examples/application/deployment.yaml`
2. Expose the deployment as a service: `oc expose deployment nginx-deployment`
3. Expose the service as a route with an override: `oc expose service nginx-deployment --overrides='{"spec":{"tls":{"termination":"reencrypt"}}}'`
4. Check the created route:

```
# With oc 4.9.x : 
❯ oc get route nginx-deployment -o yaml | grep -A 10 spec:
spec:
  host: [elided]
  port:
    targetPort: 80
  tls:
    termination: reencrypt
  to:
    kind: Service
    name: nginx-deployment
    weight: 100
  wildcardPolicy: None

# With oc 4.11.x : 
❯ oc get route nginx-deployment -o yaml | grep -A 10 spec:
spec:
  host: [elided]
  port:
    targetPort: 80
  to:
    kind: Service
    name: nginx-deployment
    weight: 100
  wildcardPolicy: None
status:
  ingress:
```

issue.title: Have support for building multi-arch operator images in Makefile and Dockerfile

labels.name: lifecycle/rotten
labels.description: Denotes an issue or PR that has aged beyond stale and will be auto-closed.

labels.name: language/go
labels.description: Issue is related to a Go operator project

issue.body:
## Feature Request

#### Describe the problem you need a feature to resolve.

Make easier the build of multi-arch operators.
Today the Dockerfile generated by operator-sdk init is explicitly setting GOARCH to amd64
RUN CGO_ENABLED=0 GOOS=linux GOARCH=amd64 GO111MODULE=on go build -a -o manager main.go
The Makefile generated by the same command is explicitly using "docker build":
docker build -t ${IMG} .

Support for multi-arch builds have been requested a few times in the past, like here:
https://github.com/operator-framework/operator-sdk/issues/3071

#### Describe the solution you'd like.

A possible approach would be to add a --multi-arch flag to operator-sdk init with default value to false for backward compatibility. When set to true
- the generated Dockerfile would have:
RUN CGO_ENABLED=0 GOOS=linux GOARCH=$TARGETPLATFORM GO111MODULE=on go build -a -o manager main.go
- the Makefile would use buildx:
docker buildx build --platform ${TARGET_PLATFORMS} -t ${IMG}.
TARGET_PLATFORMS could default to amd64 in the Makefile

A similar approach could be used for more customization like using buildah/podman instead of docker

Benefits:
- Better user experience: multi-arch builds supported directly by setting a flag. No need to retrieve the required commands and change generated files
- Control by the SDK project of the Makefile and Dockerfile customization so that upgrades to newer versions of the SDK may not override changes made by users for supporting multi-arch builds

/language go

issue.title: Bug 2029367: fix(config): Parse X.Y format minVersion and maxVersion

labels.name: bugzilla/severity-medium
labels.description: Referenced Bugzilla bug's severity is medium for the branch this PR is targeting.

labels.description: Indicates that a referenced Bugzilla bug is invalid for the branch this PR is targeting.

labels.name: lgtm
labels.description: Indicates that a PR is ready to be merged.

issue.body:
# Description

Error info is ambiguous when minVersion and maxVersion are wrong in the
ImageSetConfiguration, especially when using yaml.

The yaml unmarshaler parses unquoted X.Y values as a number, but users
intend that to be a semver version string.

The k8s yaml unmarshaler serializes to JSON and deserializes from JSON
in order to use the json marshaler's struct tags.

The json unmarshaler can't read a number into a string field, so a
custom UnmarshalJSON method is needed.

The custom json unmarshaling code would be simpler if MinVersion and
MaxVersion were extracted to a dedicated struct and inlined back into
ReleaseChannel, but there are a bunch of usages that would need to be
updated and I chose to prefer slightly-more-complicated unmarshaling
over clobbering history in a bunch of other places.

Bug 2029367
Fixes github issue #240

## Type of change

Please delete options that are not relevant.

- [x] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)

# How Has This Been Tested?

This is a client-side configuration parsing bug, so I wrote unit tests. Run `make test`

**Test Configuration**:
* Toolchain: go version go1.18.3 linux/amd64

- [x] My code follows the style guidelines of this project

labels.name: lgtm

labels.description: Referenced Bugzilla bug's severity is medium for the branch this PR is targeting.

issue.body:
When a user tries to create a new-app with a SSH based repository, `oc` fails on not being able to `git ls-remote --heads` due authentication error, i.e.:

```
$ oc new-app --v=8 --source-secret=github-repo-key --name=test-app 'git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git'
I1019 09:41:10.701737   24709 loader.go:374] Config loaded from file:  /home/otaviof/.kube/config
I1019 09:41:10.702768   24709 sourcelookup.go:316] Checking if git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git requires authentication
I1019 09:41:10.702789   24709 repository.go:450] Executing git ls-remote --heads git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git
I1019 09:41:10.702811   24709 repository.go:459] Environment:
I1019 09:41:10.702818   24709 repository.go:461] - HOME=/tmp/githome2802467764
I1019 09:41:10.702825   24709 repository.go:461] - GIT_SSH=/dev/null
I1019 09:41:10.702832   24709 repository.go:461] - GIT_CONFIG_NOSYSTEM=true
I1019 09:41:10.702837   24709 repository.go:461] - GIT_ASKPASS=true
I1019 09:41:10.704143   24709 repository.go:541] Error executing command: exit status 128
warning: Cannot check if git requires authentication.
[...]
See 'oc new-app -h' for examples.
exit status 1
``` 

This pull request removes the hardcoded `GIT_SSH=/dev/null` allowing Git to use the local SSH-Agent:

```
$ oc new-app --v=8 --source-secret=github-repo-key --name=test-app 'git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git'
I1019 09:35:20.560638   23876 loader.go:374] Config loaded from file:  /home/otaviof/.kube/config
I1019 09:35:20.561705   23876 sourcelookup.go:315] Checking if git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git requires authentication
I1019 09:35:20.561722   23876 repository.go:450] Executing git ls-remote --heads git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git
I1019 09:35:20.561742   23876 repository.go:459] Environment:
I1019 09:35:20.561747   23876 repository.go:461] - HOME=/tmp/githome2424980829
I1019 09:35:20.561750   23876 repository.go:461] - GIT_CONFIG_NOSYSTEM=true
I1019 09:35:20.561753   23876 repository.go:461] - GIT_ASKPASS=true
I1019 09:35:21.892018   23876 sourcelookup.go:94] git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git is a valid remote git repository
I1019 09:35:21.892044   23876 newapp.go:318] treating git@github.com:otaviof/nodejs-ex.git as possible source repo
[...]
--> Success
    Build scheduled, use 'oc logs -f buildconfig/test-app' to track its progress.
    Application is not exposed. You can expose services to the outside world by executing one or more of the commands below:
     'oc expose service/test-app'
    Run 'oc status' to view your app.
```

Original PR #1269 (`master`)

issue.title: Special debug code to execute after scenario step in case of special test case failures.

labels.name: lifecycle/stale
labels.description: Denotes an issue or PR has remained open with no activity and has become stale.

issue.body:
As you see in both [OCPQE-8172](https://issues.redhat.com/browse/OCPQE-8172) and [OCPQE-8117](https://issues.redhat.com/browse/OCPQE-8117) tickets, in these cases, it is difficult for us to debug test case failures or taking longer time to identify the root cause. To minimize the effort on debugging such failures , we want to introduce certain debug code to execute right after the unexpected failures during execution.
I have investigated with cucushift framework ( with my limited knowledge :) ) and made few dummy changes and that makes execution of debug statements "after scenario" step. The intention is NOT to execute debug statements for every case but need to execute only in case of failures w.r.t kube-apiserver such as,
1. xxxx:6443 connection is refused.
2. xxxx:6443 timeout.
3. server is currently unable to handle the request (get projects.project.openshift.io)
Currently i'm unable to get the test case result or it's scope to make such decision for above code. I would need your review and suggestions to achieve the solution.
Note: These are random failures and not stick to any specific test case , Hence I see that it's needs to be handled in core instead of step implementation.
Attached local execution results for both positive and negative scenarios - http://pastebin.test.redhat.com/1043194
@wangke19 @liangxia @qe-productivity-team Please share your thoughts.

issue.title: Scripts out Deployment Validation

labels.name: lifecycle/rotten
labels.description: Denotes an issue or PR that has aged beyond stale and will be auto-closed.

labels.name: approved
labels.description: Indicates a PR has been approved by an approver from all required OWNERS files.

issue.body:
Currently tests both `non-ccs` and `ccs` cluster creation using OCM.

This script assumes you're already logged into whatever OCM environment you are attempting to test.

This script also assumes you have a valid set of credentials for an IAM User: `osdCCSAdmin` in your `~/.aws/credentials` file (you pass the profile name in as the parameter).

Example:

```
$ cat ~/.aws/credentials
[osd-staging-2-ccsadmin]
aws_access_key_id = myaccesskeyid
aws_secret_access_key_id = mysecretaccesskeyid
```

Given the above file, you would call the script as such: `./hack/scripts/validate_deployment.sh -p osd-staging-2-ccsadmin`

This script runs the creation in parallel, allowing you to run the script and just wait for the output to finish.  The script also only waits for the cluster to move from `pending` to `installing` as once the cluster is `installing` the work of AWS Account Operator is complete.

Future work: Script out STS creation.
